OPPORTUNITY TITLE: Blueprint Neurotherapeutics Network (BPN): Small Molecule Drug Discovery and Development of Disorders of the Nervous System (UG3/UH3 Clinical Trial Optional)
DESCRIPTION: The Blueprint Neurotherapeutics Network (BPN) invites applications from neuroscience investigators seeking support to advance their small molecule drug discovery and development projects into the clinic. Participants in the BPN are responsible for conducting all studies that involve disease- or target-specific assays, models, and other research tools and receive funding for all activities to be conducted in their own laboratories. In addition, applicants will collaborate with NIH-funded consultants and can augment their project with NIH contract research organizations (CROs) that specialize in medicinal chemistry, pharmacokinetics, toxicology, formulations development, chemical synthesis including under Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP), and Phase I clinical testing. Projects can enter either at the Discovery stage, to optimize promising hit compounds through medicinal chemistry to the Development stage, to advance a single development candidate through Investigational New Drug (IND)-enabling toxicology studies and phase I clinical testing. Alternatively, projects can enter at the Development stage and progress in a shorter period to IND enabling toxicology studies and phase I clinical testing. BPN awardee Institutions retain their assignment of IP rights and gain assignment of IP rights from the BPN contractors (and thereby control the patent prosecution and licensing negotiations) for drug candidates developed in this program.
Description: The Blueprint Neurotherapeutics Network (BPN) invites applications from neuroscience investigators seeking support to advance their small molecule drug discovery and development projects into the clinic. Participants in the BPN are responsible for conducting all studies that involve disease- or target-specific assays, models, and other research tools and receive funding for all activities to be conducted in their own laboratories. In addition, applicants will collaborate with NIH-funded consultants and can augment their project with NIH contract research organizations (CROs) that specialize in medicinal chemistry, pharmacokinetics, toxicology, formulations development, chemical synthesis including under Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP), and Phase I clinical testing. Projects can enter either at the Discovery stage, to optimize promising hit compounds through medicinal chemistry to the Development stage, to advance a single development candidate through Investigational New Drug (IND)-enabling toxicology studies and phase I clinical testing. Alternatively, projects can enter at the Development stage and progress in a shorter period to IND enabling toxicology studies and phase I clinical testing. BPN awardee Institutions retain their assignment of IP rights and gain assignment of IP rights from the BPN contractors (and thereby control the patent prosecution and licensing negotiations) for drug candidates developed in this program.
LLM Summary:
**Description:** The Blueprint Neurotherapeutics Network (BPN) supports neuroscience researchers in advancing small molecule drug discovery and development projects to clinical stages. Participants are responsible for disease- or target-specific studies conducted in their laboratories and can collaborate with NIH-funded consultants and contract research organizations (CROs) that specialize in various aspects of drug development.

**Research Objectives:** The primary objective is to facilitate the transition of projects from the Discovery stage, where promising compounds are optimized, to the Development stage, which includes efforts to advance candidates through Investigational New Drug (IND)-enabling toxicology studies and Phase I clinical testing. Projects may enter either at the Discovery stage or directly at the Development stage.

**Expected Outcomes:** Successful implementation of the program is expected to yield novel small molecule drug candidates specifically targeting disorders of the nervous system, with awardee institutions retaining patent rights and control over the prosecution and licensing of developed drug candidates.

**Application Considerations:** Applicants must be neuroscience investigators and should be prepared to conduct their studies while collaborating with NIH resources. Institutions should be aware that they will retain IP rights and that there is potential for collaboration with specialized CROs to enhance their projects. Specific details regarding eligibility criteria or submission deadlines are not provided.
LLM Teaser: The Blueprint Neurotherapeutics Network (BPN) is seeking applications from neuroscience investigators to support small molecule drug discovery and development projects for nervous system disorders. Participants will conduct disease- or target-specific studies in their own laboratories and collaborate with NIH-funded consultants, receiving funding for all related activities.

OPPORTUNITY TITLE: Building Biomedical Engineering Education, Research, and Innovation at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU eBETA) (UG3/UH3 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
DESCRIPTION: The purpose of the Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) Biomedical Engineering, Imaging, and Technology Acceleration (BEITA) program is to enhance bioengineering and imaging research capacity, technology innovation, education and research training, and opportunities for scientific growth at HBCUs in order to utilize the Nation's full range of talent in meeting the growing need to accelerate the development and translation of high-impact biomedical innovation and technologies. The HBCU BEITA initiative will provide funding to strengthen the research capacity and technology innovation at HBCUs, accelerate technology development and implementation, and prepare students at HBCUs for careers in biomedical engineering, imaging, and technology (BEIT).

The HBCU BEITA initiative will provide funding to strengthen the research capacity and technology innovation at HBCUs, accelerate technology development and implementation, and prepare students at HBCUs for careers in biomedical engineering, imaging, and technology (BEIT).

**Research Objectives:** The program's objectives include strengthening research capacity at HBCUs, fostering technology innovation, accelerating the development and implementation of technologies, and preparing students for careers in biomedical engineering, imaging, and technology.

**Expected Outcomes:** Expected outcomes of the program include an increase in the research capabilities and technology development at HBCUs, enhanced educational opportunities in the biomedical engineering field, and improved career readiness for students pursuing careers in biomedical engineering, imaging, and technology. 

**Application Considerations:** Information not provided.

This initiative aims to utilize the nation's full range of talent to accelerate the development and translation of high-impact biomedical innovations and technologies.

OPPORTUNITY TITLE: Improving access to safe drinking water
CATEGORY: Other (see text field entitled "Explanation of Other Category of Funding Activity" for clarification)
DESCRIPTION: THIS IS A REQUEST FOR INFORMATION ONLY. This notice does not constitute a commitment by the Government. All information submitted in response to this announcement is voluntary, and the Government will not pay for information requested nor will it compensate any respondent for any cost incurred in developing information provided to the Government. Development Problem Statement USAID has considerable experience working on water infrastructure in urban and peri-urban settings such as Montserrado and Margibi, where the cost-effectiveness of reaching people in more densely-populated areas is greater. Although the percentage of the population that already has access to basic water services in the two counties is fairly high, it is estimated that the counties are home to over 100,000 people who are still using unimproved water sources. This activity would seek to sustainably eliminate the use of surface water and unimproved water sources in Montserrado and Margibi, moving everyone to at least a basic level of water service. To do so, the activity would address key systems challenges affecting water service delivery, including poor governance and financial management of water systems, lack of financing for water, lack of community involvement in designing and managing local water systems, and insufficient customer demand for basic water services, which have limited the sustainability of water investments in the past. See related documents for full information.
Description: THIS IS A REQUEST FOR INFORMATION ONLY. This notice does not constitute a commitment by the Government. All information submitted in response to this announcement is voluntary, and the Government will not pay for information requested nor will it compensate any respondent for any cost incurred in developing information provided to the Government. Development Problem Statement USAID has considerable experience working on water infrastructure in urban and peri-urban settings such as Montserrado and Margibi, where the cost-effectiveness of reaching people in more densely-populated areas is greater. Although the percentage of the population that already has access to basic water services in the two counties is fairly high, it is estimated that the counties are home to over 100,000 people who are still using unimproved water sources. This activity would seek to sustainably eliminate the use of surface water and unimproved water sources in Montserrado and Margibi, moving everyone to at least a basic level of water service. To do so, the activity would address key systems challenges affecting water service delivery, including poor governance and financial management of water systems, lack of financing for water, lack of community involvement in designing and managing local water systems, and insufficient customer demand for basic water services, which have limited the sustainability of water investments in the past. See related documents for full information.
LLM Summary:
**Description:** This initiative focuses on addressing the challenges of accessing safe drinking water in urban and peri-urban areas, specifically in Montserrado and Margibi, where over 100,000 residents still rely on unimproved water sources despite a relatively high percentage of the population having basic water services. 

**Research Objectives:** The primary objective is to sustainably eliminate the reliance on surface water and unimproved water sources in these counties, ensuring that all residents achieve at least a basic level of water service. This will involve analyzing and addressing the systemic challenges that hinder effective water service delivery, such as governance and financial management issues, financing shortages, lack of community engagement, and limited customer demand for water services.

**Expected Outcomes:** The initiative is anticipated to lead to improved access to safe drinking water for the populations in Montserrado and Margibi by enhancing the sustainability of water investments and fostering community involvement in water system management. 

**Application Considerations:** Information on specific application processes, deadlines, or requirements is not provided in the grant description. Therefore, those interested in responding or participating may need to seek additional guidance or clarify any application protocols with the appropriate authorities.
LLM Teaser: This notice serves as a request for information and does not indicate a commitment from the Government, which will not compensate any respondents for their submissions. USAID aims to leverage its experience in improving water infrastructure in urban and peri-urban areas, such as Montserrado.

OPPORTUNITY TITLE: U.S.-South Africa Program for Collaborative Biomedical Research Phase 3 (HIV/AIDS) (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
CATEGORY: Education Health Income Security and Social Services
DESCRIPTION: The purpose of this Notice of Funding Opportunity (NOFO) is to support research projects under Phase 3 of the U.S.-South Africa Program for Collaborative Biomedical Research. Research areas supported under this program include HIV/AIDS, HIV/AIDS co-morbidities and co-infections, HIV/AIDS-associated implementation science, and HIV/AIDS-associated data science. The hallmark of the U.S.-South Africa program is the development of collaborative partnerships between South African investigators and United States (U.S.) investigators. Through international collaboration, this research will advance scientific discoveries, promote sharing of technologies and approaches, and serve local public health needs and priorities in support of global HIV/AIDS research.

The hallmark of the U.S.-South Africa program is the development of collaborative partnerships between South African investigators and United States (U.S.) investigators. Through international collaboration, this research will advance scientific discoveries, promote sharing of technologies and approaches, and serve local public health needs and priorities in support of global HIV/AIDS research.

The program emphasizes the establishment of collaborative partnerships between South African and U.S. researchers.

**Research Objectives:** The program targets research areas such as HIV/AIDS, co-morbidities and co-infections associated with HIV/AIDS, implementation science related to HIV/AIDS, and data science pertaining to HIV/AIDS. The primary goal is to facilitate scientific advancements and enhance the effectiveness of public health strategies addressing HIV/AIDS.

**Expected Outcomes:** The initiative is designed to drive scientific discoveries, facilitate the sharing of technologies and methodologies, and address local and global public health needs related to HIV/AIDS. It aims to strengthen research capacity and foster international collaboration in the field.

**Application Considerations:** Information not provided.

The program emphasizes the establishment of collaborative partnerships between South African investigators and U.S. institutions.

DESCRIPTION: The National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) Division of Public Programs is accepting applications for the Public Humanities Projects program. This program supports projects that bring the ideas and insights of the humanities to life for general audiences through in-person, hybrid, or virtual programming. Projects must engage humanities scholarship to analyze significant themes in disciplines such as history, literature, ethics, and art history.

OPPORTUNITY TITLE: FY2024 Historic Preservation Fund- Save America's Treasures- Collection Grants
CATEGORY: Other (see text field entitled "Explanation of Other Category of Funding Activity" for clarification)
APPLICATION_DEADLINE: Dec 12, 2024 Electronically submitted applications must be submitted no later than 11:59 PM, ET, on the listed application due date.
DESCRIPTION: Save America’s Treasures grants from the Historic Preservation Fund provide preservation and/or conservation assistance to nationally significant historic properties and collections. For collections, the program supports museums, libraries, archives, and all other collecting institutions in addressing conservation needs of nationally significant collections including physical conservation, curation, care, and collections management. Grants are awarded through a competitive process and require a dollar-for-dollar, non-Federal match, which can be cash or documented in-kind. The grant program is administered by the National Park Service (NPS) in partnership with the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA), the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH), and the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS).There are separate opportunities for preservation and collections projects. The collections opportunity can be found under opportunity number P24AS00545. The preservation opportunity can be found under opportunity Number P24AS00544.FY2024 Public Law 118-42 provides $25.5 million for the SAT Grant Program.

The collections opportunity can be found under opportunity number P24AS00545. The preservation opportunity can be found under opportunity Number P24AS00544.FY2024 Public Law 118-42 provides $25.5 million for the SAT Grant Program.

It aims to address conservation needs related to physical conservation, curation, care, and collections management of nationally significant collections. 

**Research Objectives:** The main objectives include the conservation of significant collections, enhancement of collection management practices, and support for the preservation of nationally recognized historic properties.

**Expected Outcomes:** Successful applicants can expect improved conservation and care of their collections, enhanced management capabilities, and greater public access to historically significant materials. The program aims to strengthen the preservation of cultural heritage across various institutions.

**Application Considerations:** Applicants must participate in a competitive process and are required to provide a dollar-for-dollar non-Federal match, which may include cash or documented in-kind contributions. The grant program is administered by the National Park Service in collaboration with various national arts and humanities organizations, with distinct opportunities for preservation and collections projects. Specific details on the collections opportunity can be referenced under opportunity number P24AS00545.

The program specifically supports museums, libraries, archives, and other collecting institutions in addressing the conservation needs of their significant collections.

OPPORTUNITY TITLE: NIOSH Support for Conferences and Scientific Meetings (U13 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
DESCRIPTION: The purpose of the NIOSH Support for Conferences and Scientific Meetings (U13) is to support high quality scientific meetings, conferences, and workshops that are relevant to NIOSHs scientific mission and that promote occupational safety and health, NIOSH program priorities, and public health. The conference program is integral to the overall mission of NIOSH. An application should address and advance important areas of research in the field of occupational safety and health of particular interest to NIOSH programs and the National Occupational Research Agenda.

OPPORTUNITY TITLE: Tobacco Regulatory Science (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
DESCRIPTION: The purpose of this Notice of Funding Opportunity Announcement (NOFO) is to invite R01 applications to support biomedical and behavioral research that will provide scientific data to inform the regulation of tobacco products to protect public health. Research Projects must address the research priorities related to the regulatory authority of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Center for Tobacco Products (CTP). The awards under this NOFO will be administered by NIH using funds that have been made available through FDA CTP and the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act (P.L. 111-31). Research results from this NOFO are expected to generate findings and data that are directly relevant to informing the FDA's regulation of the manufacture, distribution, and marketing of tobacco products to protect public health.
Description: The purpose of this Notice of Funding Opportunity Announcement (NOFO) is to invite R01 applications to support biomedical and behavioral research that will provide scientific data to inform the regulation of tobacco products to protect public health. Research Projects must address the research priorities related to the regulatory authority of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Center for Tobacco Products (CTP). The awards under this NOFO will be administered by NIH using funds that have been made available through FDA CTP and the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act (P.L. 111-31). Research results from this NOFO are expected to generate findings and data that are directly relevant to informing the FDA's regulation of the manufacture, distribution, and marketing of tobacco products to protect public health.

The awards will be administered by NIH and are funded by the FDA Center for Tobacco Products (CTP) through the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act.

**Research Objectives:** The primary objective is to address research priorities that fall under the regulatory authority of the FDA CTP. The research should generate data and findings that will aid in the regulation of the manufacture, distribution, and marketing of tobacco products.

**Expected Outcomes:** The research is expected to yield significant findings and scientific data that will directly inform the FDA's regulatory strategies, ultimately contributing to improved public health outcomes related to tobacco use.

**Application Considerations:** Applicants should ensure their research proposals align with the regulatory interests of the FDA CTP and demonstrate how their work will provide relevant data to support tobacco product regulation. Information not provided regarding specific eligibility criteria or timeline for submissions.
LLM Teaser: This Notice of Funding Opportunity Announcement invites R01 applications to support biomedical and behavioral research aimed at generating scientific data for the regulation of tobacco products to protect public health. Research projects must align with the regulatory priorities of the FDA Center for Tobacco Products, and the awards will be administered by NIH.

CATEGORY: Science and Technology and other Research and Development
DESCRIPTION: NASA Human Exploration Research Opportunities (HERO) Released Notice of Funding Opportunity (NOFO), entitled, “Human Exploration Research Opportunities (HERO)” (NNJ25ZSA001N) , has been released. This NOFO will solicit applied research in support of NASA’s Human Research Program (HRP). This NOFO is available through the the NASA Solicitation and Proposal Integrated Review and Evaluation System (NSPIRES) at: https://tinyurl.com/HERO25NOFO. The research will fall into one or more categories corresponding to HRP’s five Elements: Space Radiation, Human Health Countermeasures, Exploration Medical Capability, Human Factors and Behavioral Performance, and Research Operations and Integration. This NOFO covers all aspects of research to provide human health and performance countermeasures, knowledge, technologies, and tools to enable safe, reliable, and productive human space exploration. Awards generally range from under $250K per year for focused, limited efforts (e.g., data analysis) to $1.2M per year for extensive activities (e.g., development of scientific hardware) and will be made as grants. The funds available for awards in each research opportunity offered in this NOFO range from less than one million to several million dollars. This range allows selection from a few to as many as a dozen proposals depending on the program objectives and the submission of proposals of merit. The period of performance for an award can range from one to five years. [g1] Any changes or modifications to any of these guidelines will be specified in the descriptions of the relevant research opportunities in the appendices of this solicitation. Details of the topics will be given in the appendices of the NOFO. Unless otherwise specified, appendices will use a two-step solicitation process requiring that a compliant and relevant Step-1 proposal be submitted in order to be considered to be invited to submit a Step-2 proposal. Proposal due dates will be staggered throughout the HERO open period of November 1, 2024 to October 2025. The first proposal due date (for Step-1 proposals submitted in response to Appendix A) is December 2, 2024. The electronic submission is required by the due date for proposal submission. Proposal due dates are given in the appendices, which will be posted at https://nspires.nasaprs.com. Interested proposers should monitor https://nspires.nasaprs.com or register and subscribe to the Space Operations Mission Directorate (SOMD) electronic notifications system through the NSPIRES account subscription services. New program elements or amendments to this NOFO through October 2025 will be posted in NSPIRES, after which time release of a subsequent HERO NOFO is planned. All categories of United States (U.S.) institutions are eligible to submit proposals in response to the NOFO. Principal Investigators may collaborate with universities, Federal Government laboratories, the private sector, and state and local government laboratories. In all such arrangements, the applying entity is expected to be responsible for administering the project according to the management approach presented in the proposal. NASA’s policy is to conduct research with non-U.S. organizations on a cooperative, no exchange-of-funds basis. Thank you for your continued interest in NASA. Please refer to the solicitation document for contact information.

LLM Summary:
**Description:** 

This funding opportunity is soliciting applied research to support NASA’s Human Research Program. It aims to advance knowledge and technologies necessary for human health and performance in the context of space exploration.

**Research Objectives:**

The research funded through this opportunity is expected to align with NASA’s five Elements: Space Radiation, Human Health Countermeasures, Exploration Medical Capability, Human Factors and Behavioral Performance, and Research Operations and Integration. Projects should focus on developing countermeasures, knowledge, and tools necessary for safe and effective human exploration in space.

**Expected Outcomes:**

The expected outcomes include advancements in human health and performance that enable reliable and productive human space missions. The funding will support both minor projects, such as data analysis, and major initiatives, such as the development of scientific hardware, contributing to the overall goal of enhanced safety and effectiveness in human space exploration.

**Application Considerations:**

Applicants can expect awards to vary in size, typically ranging from under $250,000 to $1.2 million per year. The total funding available for each research opportunity may extend from less than one million to several million dollars, with the period of performance for awards lasting from one to five years. Selection may favor a few significant projects or a larger number of smaller initiatives based on merit and program objectives.

OPPORTUNITY TITLE: Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program
CATEGORY: Science and Technology and other Research and Development
APPLICATION_DEADLINE: Nov 26, 2024 Broadening Participation Research Centers; Research Initiation Awards; Targeted Infusion Projects, Research on Broadening Participation in STEM Projects, Implementation Projects; Research Initiation Awards; Targeted Infusion Projects, Research on Broadening Participation in STEM Projects, Implementation Projects; Broadening Participation Research Center
DESCRIPTION: HBCU-UP provides awardsto strengthen STEM undergraduate education and research at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs).Support is available through thefollowing tracks: Targeted Infusion Projects (TIP), which provide support to achieve a short-term, well-defined goal for enhancing and innovating undergraduate STEM education at an HBCU. Research on Broadening Participation in STEMprojects (BPR), which provide support for researchthat seeks to create and study new theory-driven models and innovations related to the participation and success of underrepresented groups in STEM undergraduate education, especially African Americans. Research Initiation Awards (RIA), which provide support for STEM faculty with no prior or recent research funding to pursue research at the home institution, another research-intensive institution, an NSF-funded research center, or a national laboratory. Implementation Projects (IMP), which provide support to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts for increasing the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in STEM and enhancing their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. Broadening Participation Research Centers (BPRC),which provide support to create centers that conduct research on STEM education and broadening participation and build the intellectual infrastructure to facilitate the creation, integration, and transfer of new knowledge. Other Funding Opportunities include EArly-Concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER), Rapid Response Research (RAPID), conference, and planning grants.

Research on Broadening Participation in STEMprojects (BPR), which provide support for researchthat seeks to create and study new theory-driven models and innovations related to the participation and success of underrepresented groups in STEM undergraduate education, especially African Americans. Other Funding Opportunities include EArly-Concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER), Rapid Response Research (RAPID), conference, and planning grants.
LLM Summary:
**Description:** The program provides awards aimed at enhancing STEM undergraduate education and research specifically at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). It offers multiple tracks to support various aspects of this educational enhancement.

**Research Objectives:** The program seeks to achieve specific short-term goals in undergraduate STEM education, develop innovative approaches to increase participation and success among underrepresented groups, especially African Americans, and fund STEM faculty to initiate research. Additionally, it aims to assess and implement comprehensive strategies for increasing the number of degrees awarded in STEM fields.

**Expected Outcomes:** The anticipated outcomes include improved quality and accessibility of STEM education at HBCUs, increased participation of underrepresented groups in STEM, faculty engagement in research activities, and the establishment of research centers focused on broadening participation in STEM education.

**Application Considerations:** Information on application requirements, deadlines, and specific eligibility criteria is not provided.
LLM Teaser: HBCU-UP offers awards to enhance STEM undergraduate education and research at Historically Black Colleges and Universities through Targeted Infusion Projects (TIP) and Research on Broadening Participation in STEM projects (BPR). TIP focuses on achieving short-term goals for improving STEM education, while BPR supports research to develop and study new theories for broadening participation in STEM fields.
